content: Yesterday, December 7, 1941, a date which will live in infamy. Congress just declared war. It's official now. Everything changes today.
historicalContext: FDR's 'Day of Infamy' speech to Congress following Pearl Harbor. The declaration of war passed with only one dissenting vote.

content: Pearl Harbor succeeded beyond expectations. We sank their battleships. But their aircraft carriers were at sea. And I fear we have awakened a sleeping giant.
historicalContext: Yamamoto allegedly expressed private concerns about the long-term wisdom of attacking the United States.

content: We shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight on the landing grounds, we shall fight in the fields and in the streets. We shall never surrender.
historicalContext: Churchill's speech to Parliament after the Dunkirk evacuation. Britain stood alone against Nazi Germany.

content: The Battle of Britain is about to begin. Hitler knows he must break us in this island or lose the war. If we stand, all Europe may be free.
historicalContext: Churchill prepared Britain for the coming air war. The Battle of Britain would be won by 'the few.'

content: We've been in hiding for two years now. The same eight people, the same rooms, the same fears. But I still believe people are good at heart. I have to.
historicalContext: Anne Frank and her family hid in the Secret Annex from 1942 until their discovery in August 1944.

content: I want to write. I want to be a journalist, a famous author. When this is over, and it will be over, the world will know what happened here.
historicalContext: Anne Frank rewrote her diary with publication in mind after hearing a radio appeal for war diaries.

content: The eyes of the world are upon you. The hopes and prayers of liberty-loving people everywhere march with you. Good luck. And let us all beseech the blessing of Almighty God.
historicalContext: Eisenhower's Order of the Day to Allied troops before D-Day. He also wrote a note accepting blame if the invasion failed.

content: Jumping in three hours. Normandy. The guys are quiet, checking gear. Writing letters home. Some praying. I'm doing all three.
historicalContext: 101st Airborne paratroopers jumped into Normandy hours before the beach landings on D-Day.

content: Made it. Don't know where I am. Lost half my squad in the drop. Can hear firing everywhere. Found some guys from the 82nd. We're moving. Somewhere.
historicalContext: Many paratroopers landed scattered across Normandy. Small groups formed impromptu units and fought toward objectives.

content: An army is a team. It lives, eats, sleeps, and fights as a team. This individuality stuff is a bunch of nonsense. The bilious bastards who write that stuff don't know any more about real battle than they know about fornicating.
historicalContext: Part of Patton's famous speech to the Third Army before D-Day. Profane, motivating, and effective.

content: If I'm right, the invasion will come in Normandy. If I'm wrong, it will come in Calais where everyone expects it. Either way, the first 24 hours will be decisive.
historicalContext: Rommel suspected Normandy but was overruled. On D-Day, he was in Germany celebrating his wife's birthday.

content: Stalingrad. Day 147. They hold the grain elevator. We hold the factory. Between us, rubble. We fight for every floor. Every room. Every corner.
historicalContext: The Battle of Stalingrad became the deadliest battle in human history. Fighting was often hand-to-hand.

content: Operation Uranus begins. Two million men. They don't know we're coming. When the snow settles, there will be no Sixth Army.
historicalContext: Zhukov's counteroffensive encircled the German Sixth Army at Stalingrad. 91,000 would eventually surrender.

content: No food for three days. Ammunition running low. The cold is worse than the Russians. They told us we'd be home by Christmas. Which Christmas?
historicalContext: Trapped German soldiers at Stalingrad faced starvation, frostbite, and constant attack. Supplies never came.

content: I came through and I shall return. They told me to leave the Philippines. I didn't want to. But I'll be back. That's a promise.
historicalContext: MacArthur was ordered to leave the Philippines as it fell to Japan. His 'I shall return' became a rallying cry.

content: People of the Philippines, I have returned. Rally to me. Let the indomitable spirit of Bataan and Corregidor lead on.
historicalContext: MacArthur waded ashore at Leyte Gulf, fulfilling his promise. The photo of his return became iconic.

content: Midway. They thought they had surprise. We knew they were coming. Four carriers sunk. The Pacific war just changed direction.
historicalContext: The Battle of Midway was the turning point in the Pacific. American codebreakers had revealed Japanese plans.

content: Built my 50th B-24 bomber today. My hands are raw. My back aches. But somewhere out there, boys are flying planes I built. That's something.
historicalContext: Willow Run produced a B-24 every hour at its peak. Women made up much of the workforce.

content: They said Black men couldn't fly. Couldn't fight. Couldn't lead. We proved them wrong at every altitude. The Red Tails never lost a bomber we escorted.
historicalContext: The 332nd Fighter Group compiled an outstanding record. Their distinctive red-tailed P-51s were welcomed by bomber crews.

content: Paris! Paris outraged! Paris broken! Paris martyrized! But Paris liberated! Liberated by its own people with the help of the armies of France!
historicalContext: De Gaulle spoke at the Hôtel de Ville after Paris was liberated. He emphasized French agency in their own liberation.

content: United the Resistance today. Communists, Gaullists, socialists, all at one table. They hate each other. But they hate the Germans more. That's enough.
historicalContext: Moulin unified the fractured French Resistance under the National Council. He was captured and killed weeks later.

content: I volunteered to be sent to Auschwitz. To see what was happening. To organize resistance. What I found... no report can capture it. They must know. The world must know.
historicalContext: Pilecki escaped Auschwitz after 2.5 years and wrote extensive reports. The Allies largely ignored his warnings.

content: Never shall I forget that night, the first night in camp, which has turned my life into one long night. Never shall I forget those flames.
historicalContext: Elie Wiesel arrived at Auschwitz in May 1944. His memoir 'Night' would become one of the most important Holocaust testimonies.

content: I love the infantry because they are the underdogs. They are the mud-rain-frost-and-wind boys. They have no comforts, and they even learn to live without the necessities.
historicalContext: Ernie Pyle won a Pulitzer for his columns about ordinary soldiers. He was killed by a sniper on Ie Shima in 1945.

content: They tried to beat our language out of us at boarding school. Now that same language is winning the war. The Diné bizaad cannot be broken.
historicalContext: Navajo Code Talkers used their language to transmit unbreakable messages. Many had been punished for speaking Navajo as children.

content: Climbed on a burning tank destroyer and held off a German company with the .50 cal. Not because I'm brave. Because I was too scared to run and too angry to die.
historicalContext: At Holtzwihr, Murphy single-handedly held off German infantry, earning the Medal of Honor. He was 19.

content: Blessed is the match consumed in kindling flame. Blessed is the flame that burns in the heart's secret places. I wrote that. Now I'm living it.
historicalContext: Hannah Szenes parachuted into Yugoslavia to rescue Hungarian Jews. She was captured, tortured, and executed at age 23.

content: Bastogne. Nuts to the Germans. The 101st held. We broke through. Merry Christmas, you magnificent bastards.
historicalContext: Patton's Third Army relieved besieged Bastogne during the Battle of the Bulge, turning the tide of Hitler's last offensive.

content: Berlin. The Reichstag is burning. Our flag is going up. 27 million dead. But we won. Mother Russia won.
historicalContext: Soviet forces raised the flag over the Reichstag. The famous photo was staged but the victory was real.

content: I have a terrific headache. Going to rest now. The war is almost won. Harry can handle things from here.
historicalContext: FDR's last words before his fatal stroke. He died at Warm Springs, Georgia, weeks before Germany surrendered.

content: VE Day. The war in Europe is over. We may allow ourselves a brief period of rejoicing. But let us not forget for a moment the toil and effort that lie ahead.
historicalContext: Churchill announced Victory in Europe from Downing Street. The war with Japan would continue for three more months.

content: We just liberated a camp. Dachau. I've seen combat. I've seen death. I've never seen anything like this. I can't unsee it. None of us can.
historicalContext: American troops liberating concentration camps were shocked by what they found. Many took photos as evidence.

content: They've given me a choice. Trial for treason, or poison and a hero's funeral. My family will be safe if I take the poison. Some choice.
historicalContext: Rommel was implicated in the July 20 plot against Hitler. He took poison; the regime announced he died of wounds.

content: Stalingrad is ours. The Germans are surrendering in waves. Frozen, starving men walking like ghosts. They came for our city. They found their graves.
historicalContext: The German Sixth Army surrendered at Stalingrad. Of 91,000 captured, only about 6,000 ever returned to Germany.

content: War's over. They're sending us home from the factory. 'Thanks for your service, girls.' The boys are coming back. We're supposed to forget we could do this.
historicalContext: After the war, millions of women were pushed out of industrial jobs to make room for returning veterans.

content: Never in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so few. The RAF is holding. Just barely, but holding.
historicalContext: Churchill's tribute to RAF Fighter Command during the Battle of Britain. Around 3,000 pilots defended Britain against the Luftwaffe.

content: Dunkirk beach. Thousands of us waiting. Stukas coming every hour. Little boats from England - fishing boats, pleasure craft, anything that floats. Getting us home one boatload at a time.
historicalContext: The Dunkirk evacuation rescued 338,000 Allied soldiers using a flotilla of military and civilian vessels.

content: London again last night. Third time this week the sirens went. Kids sleeping in the tube station, old ladies knitting like nothing's happening. We don't talk about being scared. Just carry on.
historicalContext: The Blitz saw continuous German bombing of London from September 1940 to May 1941. Underground stations became shelters.

content: Iwo Jima. Day 3. That mountain is still spitting fire at us. Every inch of this island costs us. The black sand smells like sulfur. Like hell itself.
historicalContext: The Battle of Iwo Jima lasted 36 days with nearly 7,000 American deaths. The volcanic island was crucial for bomber bases.

content: They raised the flag on Suribachi today. Photographer got a picture. Guys are saying it'll be famous. Right now I just want off this rock alive.
historicalContext: Joe Rosenthal's photograph of the flag raising on Mount Suribachi became one of the most iconic images of WWII.

content: Executive Order 9066 signed. Japanese Americans on the West Coast will be relocated to internment camps. For security, they say. My own advisors pushed for this. I hope history understands.
historicalContext: FDR's order led to the forced relocation of 120,000 Japanese Americans. It remains one of the worst civil liberties violations in US history.

content: North Africa. Sand in everything. Rommel pushes us forward, the British push us back. El Alamein. We're running out of fuel. Running out of time.
historicalContext: The Second Battle of El Alamein was a decisive British victory that ended Axis hopes of taking Egypt and the Suez Canal.

content: Before Alamein we never had a victory. After Alamein we never had a defeat. This is not the end. It is not even the beginning of the end. But it is, perhaps, the end of the beginning.
historicalContext: Churchill's speech at Mansion House after El Alamein. The tide of the war was turning against the Axis.

content: Kursk. Biggest tank battle in history. The sky is black with smoke. Steel monsters everywhere. We're holding. We have to hold.
historicalContext: The Battle of Kursk involved 6,000 tanks and 2 million soldiers. It was the largest tank battle in history and marked Germany's last major offensive in the East.

content: Market Garden failed. We held the bridge at Arnhem too long. British paratroopers got slaughtered. Another brilliant plan that cost us thousands.
historicalContext: Operation Market Garden aimed to end the war by Christmas 1944. The 'bridge too far' at Arnhem led to heavy Allied casualties.

content: Today, here on this deck, the guns are silent. A great tragedy has ended. A great victory has been won. Let us pray that peace be now restored.
historicalContext: Japan formally surrendered aboard USS Missouri in Tokyo Bay, ending World War II.

content: Okinawa. 82 days. They call it the Typhoon of Steel. Kamikazes hit the fleet every day. The Japanese fight to the last man. This is what invading Japan would look like.
historicalContext: The Battle of Okinawa was the bloodiest Pacific battle. Over 100,000 Japanese soldiers and 12,000 Americans died.

content: Something happened in Japan. They're saying a single bomb destroyed an entire city. Hiroshima. What kind of bomb does that? What have we made?
historicalContext: The atomic bombing of Hiroshima killed 80,000 people instantly and many more from radiation. It was the first use of nuclear weapons in war.

content: VJ Day! The war is over! Really over! Dancing in the streets. Strangers kissing. My husband is coming home. Four years. Finally coming home.
historicalContext: Japan's surrender sparked celebrations worldwide. The famous 'VJ Day Kiss' photo in Times Square captured the moment.

content: Liberated. American soldiers gave us food. Some ate too fast and died. Freedom came too late for my father. He died in my arms three months ago. I am alone.
historicalContext: Buchenwald was liberated on April 11, 1945. Elie Wiesel was 16. His father had died of dysentery and exhaustion.

content: The Death of Captain Waskow. I saw his men come down the mountain with his body on a mule. They touched his hand, straightened his clothes. Said goodbye. War makes everything raw.
historicalContext: Ernie Pyle's column about Captain Henry Waskow became one of the most famous pieces of war journalism ever written.

content: Escorted bombers to Berlin today. 1,600 miles round trip. Lost two planes to flak. Coming home to a segregated mess hall. We fight fascism abroad while living under it at home.
historicalContext: The Tuskegee Airmen flew their longest mission to Berlin on March 24, 1945. Despite heroic service, they returned to segregated America.

content: I am General de Gaulle. France has lost a battle. France has not lost the war. We will continue to fight. From London, from the Empire, wherever free French still stand.
historicalContext: De Gaulle's radio broadcast from London after France's fall launched the Free French movement and established him as leader of the resistance.

content: Monte Cassino. Fourth assault. The Americans destroyed the monastery and it made things worse. Now the rubble gives us perfect cover. Still we're dying on these slopes.
historicalContext: The Battle of Monte Cassino lasted four months and cost 55,000 Allied casualties. The ancient monastery was controversially bombed.

content: Peleliu. The code works. Commands go through in seconds. The Japanese are listening, but they'll never break it. Our language is our weapon.
historicalContext: Navajo Code Talkers served in every major Marine operation in the Pacific. Their code was never broken.

content: They caught me. Caluire. Someone talked. The Gestapo is here. I will say nothing. They can break my body but not the Resistance. Max has already won.
historicalContext: Jean Moulin was captured by Klaus Barbie and tortured. He died without revealing any names. His code name was Max.

content: Peter and I kissed today in the attic. With everything happening, this moment of normal teenage life. Tomorrow could be our last. Today, we're alive.
historicalContext: Anne Frank developed a romantic relationship with Peter van Pels while in hiding. Her diary captures normal adolescence amid extraordinary circumstances.

content: The Warsaw Ghetto is rising. They're fighting with pistols against tanks. They know they'll die. But they'll die fighting. That matters.
historicalContext: The Warsaw Ghetto Uprising lasted nearly a month. Poorly armed Jewish fighters held off the Nazis longer than some countries.

content: Tobruk has fallen. 33,000 prisoners. Churchill will be furious. But we're stretched too thin. I need fuel. I need tanks. Berlin sends nothing but congratulations.
historicalContext: The fall of Tobruk was a major victory for Rommel but his Afrika Korps was overextended. Supply shortages would doom his campaign.

content: They asked how I did it. I don't know. Training takes over. Rage takes over. You don't think about medals. You think about the guys next to you. That's all.
historicalContext: Audie Murphy became the most decorated American soldier of WWII. He received every military combat award for valor available.
